title: About Charting Waterloo Region
text: This blog is dedicated to keeping Waterloo Region residents informed about their community using charts full of interesting data about the Region.

title: Stock Price Visualization Tool
text:
Welcome to my stock-price visualization tool!

This simple tool pulls stock price data from Yahoo Finance for the stock symbol and date range you specify (see the Yahoo Finance page to look up symbols for the stocks you wish to visualize).
You also have the option to view the prices on a logarithmic scale and to adjust the historical prices to their present values using CPI data from FRED.
Happy charting!

title: Kitchener School Collisions
text: The interactive map below reports the types and number of collisions within 250m of schools in Kitchener. Hover over a bubble to see the school name and click on it to see collision details. Bubbles containing a number indicate multiple schools. Click on them to zoom in and see bubbles for the individual schools.

Bubbles containing a number indicate multiple schools. Click on them to zoom in and see bubbles for the individual schools.

title: Open Data Overview
text:
The Open Data Charter specifies six principles that should guide the provision of open data:

Open by Default - we shouldn’t have to ask officials for the data we want
Timely and Comprehensive - we need relevant data in its complete, unmodified form
Accessible and Usable - we need easy-to-find, machine-readable data
Comparable and Interoperable - we need data that can easily talk to each other
For Improved Governance and Citizen Engagement - we need data to hold officials to account
For Inclusive Development and Innovation - we need data to spur inclusive economic development



The ODC guidance on implementing Principle 3 focuses more on accessibility than usability, emphasizing that data should be easily discoverable, accessible, and barrier-free. To these ends, it asks providers to pledge they will release free, unrestricively licensed data in multiple open, standardized formats on a central portal that permits anonymous access and downloading. These four pledges are very specific and relatively easy to implement, but they do very little to enhance data’s usability (open, standardized formats help most with this). Only the fifth and final pledge stresses that providers should ensure data can be used effectively by the widest range of users, and goes on to suggest this can be achieved by promoting data literacy, building capacity for effective use of open data, and helping people effectively understand how public resources are used. All three suggestions are vague, difficult to implement, and, most important, place the onus on users to get better at using the data rather than on providers to get better at making the data more usable, regardless of users’ data literacy. To implement a suggestion like, “Governments may provide educational and training resources for citizens, government employees, and civil society and private sector representatives to ensure they have the skills necessary to access, read, understand, and manipulate data,” governments would have to invest significant sums of money to achieve a goal that could only ever hope to be achieved in the very long term, and even then with a very low chance of success given persistent difficulties in raising citizens’ financial literacy and ongoing problems with basic literacy and numeracy among Canada’s youth.

title: Open Data Overview
text: The ODC guidance on implementing Principle 3 focuses more on accessibility than usability, emphasizing that data should be easily discoverable, accessible, and barrier-free. To these ends, it asks providers to pledge they will release free, unrestricively licensed data in multiple open, standardized formats on a central portal that permits anonymous access and downloading. These four pledges are very specific and relatively easy to implement, but they do very little to enhance data’s usability (open, standardized formats help most with this). Only the fifth and final pledge stresses that providers should ensure data can be used effectively by the widest range of users, and goes on to suggest this can be achieved by promoting data literacy, building capacity for effective use of open data, and helping people effectively understand how public resources are used. All three suggestions are vague, difficult to implement, and, most important, place the onus on users to get better at using the data rather than on providers to get better at making the data more usable, regardless of users’ data literacy. To implement a suggestion like, “Governments may provide educational and training resources for citizens, government employees, and civil society and private sector representatives to ensure they have the skills necessary to access, read, understand, and manipulate data,” governments would have to invest significant sums of money to achieve a goal that could only ever hope to be achieved in the very long term, and even then with a very low chance of success given persistent difficulties in raising citizens’ financial literacy and ongoing problems with basic literacy and numeracy among Canada’s youth.

title: Kitchener School Collisions
text:
In Figure 1 we see that the number of pedestrian collisions per year has been steadily decreasing since 2015. In total, there were 231 collisions involving pedestrians during the study period.








Figure 1: Total pedestrian collisions per year








In Figure 2 we see that just over half (129/231 or 56%) of all pedestrian collisions occurred at locations with some type of traffic control in place.








Figure 2: Total pedestrian collisions by traffic control type








Table 1 reports the schools that had at least one pedestrian collision within 250m. In total there were 28 pedestrian collisions within 250m of a school (one of these occurred within 250m of two schools, so the number of collisions below add to 29).

Table 1: Schools with at least one pedestrian collision within 250m







Figure 3 compares the number of pedestrian collisions inside and outside the 250m boundary of schools on regular school days (i.e., days schools were not locked down due to the pandemic). As with total pedestrian collisions in Figure 1 above, we see steadily declining trends inside and outside the 250m boundary.








Figure 3: Number of pedestrian collisions outside and inside 250m of a school








Consistent with Figure 2 above, Figure 4 shows that just over half (15/28 or 54%) of pedestrian collisions near schools occurred at locations with some type of traffic control in place.








Figure 4: Traffic controls in effect at pedestrian collisions near schools








Table 2 reports the number of collisions of any type that occurred within 250m of a school, with the number of pedestrian and cyclist collisions broken out from all other types of collisions. The vast majority (~95%) of collisions near schools involve neither pedestrians nor cyclists.

title: Kitchener School Collisions
text:
In Figure 1 we see that the number of pedestrian collisions per year has been steadily decreasing since 2015. In total, there were 231 collisions involving pedestrians during the study period.








Figure 1: Total pedestrian collisions per year

title: Kitchener School Collisions
text:
In Figure 2 we see that about half of all pedestrian collisions occurred at locations with some type of traffic control in place.








Figure 2: Total pedestrian collisions by traffic control type

title: Kitchener School Collisions
text:
The interactive map in Figure 5 reports the types and number of collisions that took place on a school day between 6AM and 6PM within 250m of schools in Kitchener. Hover over a bubble to see the school name and click on it to see collision details. A bubble with a number indicates multiple underlying schools. Click on it to zoom in and see bubbles for the individual schools.








Figure 5: Collisions within 250m of a school on regular school days from 6am-6pm

title: Kitchener School Collisions
text:
In Figure 2 we see that just over half (129/231 or 56%) of all pedestrian collisions occurred at locations with some type of traffic control in place.








Figure 2: Total pedestrian collisions by traffic control type

title: Kitchener School Collisions
text:
Figure 3 compares the number of pedestrian collisions inside and outside the 250m boundary of schools on regular school days (i.e., days schools were not locked down due to the pandemic). As with total pedestrian collisions in Figure 1 above, we see steadily declining trends inside and outside the 250m boundary.








Figure 3: Number of pedestrian collisions outside and inside 250m of a school

title: Kitchener School Collisions
text:
Consistent with Figure 2 above, Figure 4 shows that just over half (15/28 or 54%) of pedestrian collisions near schools occurred at locations with some type of traffic control in place.








Figure 4: Traffic controls in effect at pedestrian collisions near schools
